physDesc.p: Three pages typewritten in black ink. Archival notes read "Mrs Richard Aldington" in pencil at the top of the first page. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I have waited in vain for your second letter about Flint’s and Fletcher’s opinions in regard to my "Lacquer Prints", but although it is two weeks since I received your last letter, I have had no other. We can no longer delay going to press.

I rather thought you might send me some more of Flint’s things, as his contribution is short, but in a letter I had from him this morning, he does not mention the subject, so I suppose I may take it that nothing more will come.

Fletcher advised me to send "Lacquer Prints" so I suppose his permission is given and I hardly think that Flint will disapprove. Whether or not you have sent them to Lawrence, I do not know, but I trust that I am doing right in considering that they are satisfactory.

Of course, as you say, we must do everything that Richard wants, and I have changed the poems in accordance with his list with one exception. I have not included "Middle Ages" because I really do not think that the American public would care for it, and I am more anxious than any one else to have Richard well liked over here. His poetry is, to my mind, so exceedingly beautiful that I cannot bear to print anything that I think people would not understand, as I want his reputation to grow by leaps and bounds.

I am glad to say that I have sold two of his poems to "The Seven Arts", namely, "Leave Taking" and "On the March". Of course I cannot place any of the others now that are coming out in the Imagist Anthology, and I am afraid it would be impossible to think of publishing "Malady" and "Middle Ages" over here.

Richard’s contribution now runs: "Vicarious Atonement", "Bondage", "A Moments Interlude", "Field Manoeuvres", "On the March", "Leave Taking", "Inarticulate Grief", "Captive", "R.V. and Another", and "Prayer". The last one I absolutely insist upon having as I love it so much. This is more than the seven titles which Richard is really entitled to, being, in fact, ten, but the space is no more than you have, as well as I can calculate it, and not as much as Fletcher’s, so I think we can strain a point.

I have included your new contribution exactly as you sent it; that is, "The God", "Adonis", "Pygmalion" and "Eurydice", taking out your "Tribute". The other contributions remain as they were when I wrote you last.

I shall have to put in the acknowledgements a word of thanks to Arthur Davison Ficke, as I got the original of my adaptation of the Japanese poet Yakura Sanjin from his book "Chats on Japanese Prints".
I have an appointment with Mr. Scaife on the firm of Houghton, Mifflin & Co. on Wednesday, when I shall hand him this manuscript.

Fletcher has sent me a book of his which he wants Houghton-Mifflin to take and in which two of the poems of his contribution appear; namely, "Lincoln" and "Armies", but I think we can make the arrangement which we have done before that our volume appears a month or two in advance of his. If I cannot do that, I don’t know what the dickens I shall do, but I am not going to cross that bridge until I get to it.

Our statement has come in from Houghton, Mifflin & Co. for the six months ending January 31, 1917, but I do not think it is quite correct, and I am going to speak to Mr. Scaife about it and get it fixed on Wednesday, so I cannot send you all your shares until after that date.

I have five dollars more which I have collected from Brown to send, also, which leaves him only five dollars to pay on the thirty dollars he agreed to pay Richard last year. I think then we shall have to give him another year before we dun him for more royalties for Richard’s "Images".
I also have a twenty dollar check here which "The Seven Arts" sent me for the two poems they have taken.
I will put all this, together with his share of the Imagist royalties and yours, in a draft and send it to you as soon as I have had my interview with Scaife.
I imagine that now we are so near the verge of war that the sailings will be uncertain and for that reason I think it is not wise to wait for further word from you.
I am thankful that our government has taken a definite stand and that we may no longer appear to the world to hold a neutrality which we certainly do not feel.
body.closer: With lots of love, dear Hilda, Affectionately,
